Package org.agilewiki.jactor2.core.messaging

Events, Requests, Responses and Exception Handling

See: Description

  • Interface Summary 
    Interface Description
    AsyncResponseProcessor<RESPONSE_TYPE>
    A AsyncResponseProcessor is an application callback to handle the response from a request.
    ExceptionHandler<RESPONSE_TYPE>
    Exception handlers are used to alter how exceptions are processed.
    Message
    Message wraps the user/application AsyncRequest/Event which are queued in the Actor's message processor's inbox.
    MessageSource
    A source of messages, and which must be able to handle a response.
  • Class Summary 
    Class Description
    AsyncRequest<RESPONSE_TYPE>
    AsyncRequest instances are used for passing both 1-way and 2-way buffered messages between actors.
    BoundResponseProcessor<RESPONSE_TYPE>
    A thread-safe wrapper for a AsyncResponseProcessor.
    BoundResponseProcessor.ContinuationEvent<RESPONSE_TYPE>
    The request used to pass the response and the wrapped AsyncResponseProcessor back to the original target processing.
    Event<TARGET_ACTOR_TYPE extends Actor>
    An Event instance is used to pass one-way unbuffered messages to any number of Actor objects.
    EventBus<TARGET_ACTOR_TYPE extends Actor>
    Publishes events to subscribers.
    RequestBase<RESPONSE_TYPE>  
    RequestBase.CallResponseProcessor
    A subclass of AsyncResponseProcessor that is used as a place holder when the RequestBase.call method is used.
    RequestBase.Pender
    Pender is used by the RequestBase.call method to block the current thread until a result is available and then either return the result or rethrow it if the result is an exception.
    ResponseCounter<RESPONSE_TYPE>
    When multiple requests have been sent, ResponseCounter can be used to track the number of requests that have not yet completed.
    SignalResponseProcessor
    Used to flag a message as a 1-way message.
    SyncRequest<RESPONSE_TYPE>  
  • Exception Summary 
    Exception Description
    ServiceClosedException
    This exception is thrown when sending a AsyncRequest to a different context and that context is closed.

Package org.agilewiki.jactor2.core.messaging Description

Events, Requests, Responses and Exception Handling

There are two types of messaging, 1-way (events) and 2-way (request/response).

Event Messages

Event messages are created and passed using subclasses of the Event class. An event is not bound to an actor instance, so the same event can be used to send messages to any number of actors. And when passing an event message to an actor, the message is given to the target actor's processing immediately, without buffering.

AsyncRequest/Response Messages

In contrast, request messages are created and passed using anonymous subclasses of the AsyncRequest class, with these anonymous classes present within the actor where the request message is evaluated. Response messages are simply request messages to which a response has been assigned. AsyncRequest and response messages are aggregated and sent in blocks to reduce the overhead of having to pass individual messages.

No messages are being processed when a message block is sent. So when the last message block is sent, the thread migrates to the destination message processor along with that block. More often than not, only a single block of messages is sent, so thread migration significantly reduces the overhead of message passing.

Exception Handling

Exception handlers are used to process otherwise uncaught exceptions. But if there is no exception handler, or if an exception is thrown by an exception handler, then the exception is returned as a response, though if the current message being processed is an event then the exception is simply logged. When a response message that holds an exception is processed by the source message processor, the exception is rethrown within the source actor rather than being pass back to the actor as a valid response.

Before an event or a request is processed, the current exception handler is set to null. The application logic specific to that event or request then has the option of assigning an exception handler via the MessageProcessor.setExceptionHandler method. When a request message is sent, the current exception handler is saved in the request message and subsequently restored when a response is received.
